quoteFirst: Once a year, Charles d'Ernemont, impelled by a sort of subconscious will-power, came downstairs, took the exact road which his father had taken, walked across the garden and sat down either on the steps of the rotunda, which you see here, in the picture, or on the kerb of the well. At
quoteLast: , he rose and went indoors again; and until his death, which occurred in 1820, he never once failed to perform this incomprehensible pilgrimage. Well, the day on which this happened was invariably the 15th of April, the anniversary of the arrest.
title: The Confessions of Arsène Lupin
author: Leblanc, Maurice, 1864-1941

quoteLast: --'Messenger returned with articles which will be sent by 5.30 train, as requested.'"
title: Curiosities of Civilization
author: Wynter, Andrew, 1819-1876

quoteFirst: On the 1st it rises at 1:44 a. m.; on the 15th at 12:49 a. m.; and on the 30th at 11:45 p. m. At
quoteLast: , on the 17th, it will be 1° 11′ north of the moon.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: "Surprised at such carelessness. Ahem!" Jerry teased. "If you want to know the time, it is
quoteLast: . Your kindred spirit should appear in three minutes."
title: Marjorie Dean, College Sophomore
author: Chase, Josephine, -1931
